column4: guys i read somewhere that running gdm as root or gnome-session could mess up some gnome config things and you had to remove or change permissions to some gnome dir in your home. could anybody refresh my memory? im searching about this and could find any discouragement to running it as sudo
Theres no need to run gdm as root
You need root commands done use sudo.
if you start gdm from a TTY then it requires "sudo /etc/init.d/gdm start". But thats not saying that it runs with the root account.
but what doesnt let me sleep is to know why they discouraged tu run it as root
sudo run as root, i mean, they said dont run it with sudo
root account is not needed in ubuntu. sudo or gksudo can run anything with root privledges.
and it wants just because theres no need, its because it could mess up your system. and i wanna know why, why exactly does running gdm or gnome-session with sudo/as root breaks up your system

Doing that in itself is no danger at all. The danger comes with the power that is given to the user. You can break things that a normal account user doesnt normally have access to do for good reasons.

and unless you know what your doing root account isnt activated out of the box anyways. If you go looking for it and turn it on. Well then thats your own responsibility to know what goes along with that.
Well you either knew or didnt. And you asked so I assumed you didnt. hehe
OMG dude make your mind up. You either know this or you dont. We just explained this.
Only time you need permission to remove a file is if your not the owner.
If you login as root or use gksudo nautilus you can do whatever you want.
